title: College Assembly
description: This activity aims to enhance the general knowledge of students in fields outside of their major studies. Topics presented at the Assemblies include culture, science, art and social issues. Six to eight large-scale assemblies attended by more than 1300 students, held in Sir Run Run Shaw Hall and a number of smaller assemblies, held on the College and other University campus, are organised each year for students’ selection. Each assembly consist of topical discussion, College session, Student Union session, and award presentation to outstanding staff and students.

syllabus: Guests from various organizations and fields are invited to give speeches at College Assemblies; other formats like group discussion and performance may be arranged as well. A wide range of themes including culture, art, science, social affairs, as well as those for enhancing personal growth of students will be arranged for our College Assemblies.每次書院聚會設專題探討，邀請各界專家、學者作嘉賓，以增進同學對文化、藝術、科學及社會問題之認識，及在個人成長方面有所提升。採用之形式包括講座、討論、表演等。

title: Bacchus: Exploring Grape Wine
requirements:
For United College Year 2 and Year 3 students only.
Not for HTMG students.
description: Wine weaves in with human history from its very beginnings and developed into one of the foremost products of civilization. Great wines have their roots in the customs, traditions and history of their home ground. Celebration of vine and wine is often associated with the legend and worship of Bacchus, the wine God. Similarly, the origins of fermenting and drinking wine in China go far back in time. Tu Kang 杜康is a household name. It is no doubt that wine occupies an important place in the culture and life of the Chinese people. This course leads students on a cultural journey on wine around the world. It introduces to students a historical perspective on wine and its role in society. In addition, it provides students with basic knowledge on wine appreciation, and the relationship among wine, food and culture. Students can develop the skill to taste wines of common production regions and grape varieties. They can develop a positive understanding on various aspects of life through appreciation of wine culture.
outcome: Upon successful completion of this course, students will have acquired basic knowledge on appreciation, selection, serving, and tasting of wines.  In addition, students should be able to:  understand the relationship of social, historical and cultural factors that interact with wines, and health and social issues associated with alcoholism.  use basic terminology to describe the sensory properties of wines and evaluate wines by tasting link cuisine art and lifestyle, and understand the concepts of wine and food matching. assess wines for basic attributes, varietal character, terroir, and basic wine styles  discuss tradition, historical, and geographical characteristics and diversity of wines of the Old World and New World countries, and various country systems for classification of wines. Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme: describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields; demonstrate the ability to think independently and innovatively; cultivate comprehensive views to appreciate different cultures; and develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork.
syllabus: The topics include cultural history of wine and its role in society; descriptions of major wine types, wine-producing regions, grape varieties, and vintages; explanations of label terminology and wine production methods; techniques for opening and serving wine; and an introduction to sensory training and comparative tasting methods.   1. The Ways of Wine and Society  • History of wines and different cultural tastes throughout the civilization evolution • Sensory evaluation of wines – the science and practice of wine tasting, assessment techniques, the senses and how they work  • Wines and cuisine – principles of wine and food matching  • The rituals of wine – factors governing selection, storage and serving of wines   2. Vinification and Viticulture • The vine species and dominant international vs. regional grape varietals  • Terroir (soil, temperature, rainfall, slopes), yield and quality of wines  • In the vineyard and the winegrower’s year  • The art of the winemakers – fermentation, and white and red wine making processes   3. Wines and Travel - The World of Wines • The vine conquers the world – regions where Vitis Vinifera has developed are also regions where various civilizations reached peak of development  • New World versus Old World competition – stress on varietal as opposed to geographical, distinctions, identities, and labeling  • Leading wine production countries – their history, local culture, geographic location, famous wine regions and wine labeling laws (e.g. Appellation d'origine contrôlée (AOC) in France and Denominazione di Origine Controllata (DOC) in Italy)

title: Leadership in Practice
requirements: For United College Year 2 and Year 3 students only.
description: It has been well established that experiential training is an excellent means of developing leadership, confidence, team spirit and other qualities of character. For many years the development of such qualities has been recognized as being of high importance by the senior management of the academic, non-government and commercial organizations. Leadership is best learned by doing. This course will explore and examine leadership theory and practice through experiential learning in the outdoor and a different setting rather than studying mainly in a classroom. It provides students with a structured, supervised programme of participation in the practice of leadership and teambuilding. The goal of this course is to help students acquire practical skills and judgment to develop their leadership qualities. On completion of this course, students will be able to identify and achieve their goals at a comparatively earlier stage in life.

title: Design Thinking Approach to Innovation
requirements:
For United College year 2 or year 3 students.
Not for IBBA major students.
description: The course aims to develop “T-shaped” characters who can develop the depth of expertise in a single field (one’s major as represented by the vertical bar of the T) while acquiring the ability to communicate and collaborate with others from different disciplines (the horizontal bar of the T) to address challenges. The ability to connect horizontally is “design thinking”. Individuals equipped with the ability to think as a designer will be able to innovate, tackle complex problems and manage changes in real life situations. With “design thinking” or by “thinking as a designer”, students can begin to understand how our world has come to its current form through intended and unintended design. Knowing that the only thing that is not designed, is nature, humans need to learn where to draw the line. By acquiring a designer’s mindset in looking at the world, each person can do one’s part to be a responsible and conscious prosumer of design. This includes utilizing eco-friendly artifacts and designing one’s learning, career and life experience on this planet in a responsible way.
outcome: On completion of the module, students are expected to be able to: Understand the background that gives rise to the experience economy, network society, and design thinking movement; Understand what “design thinking” or “thinking as a designer” means and be able to participate in a design process; Utilize role playing, prototyping and visualization aids to frame and solve problems in a group setting; and Apply design thinking in one’s life to become a modern day “educated person”.Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme: describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields; demonstrate the ability to think independently and innovatively; cultivate comprehensive views to appreciate different cultures; and develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork.
syllabus: 1. Experience Economy, Network Society, and Design Thinking (a) Trace the rise of the experience economy and network society (b) Integrate user experience (UX), technology platform (TP), and business model (BM) to foster innovation (c) Understand the relationship between creativity, design and innovation (d) Facilitate the design process through divergent and convergent thinking methods and techniques in a multidisciplinary team context (e) Manage team formation and project implementation with digital tools  2. Managing the Design Process (a) Gain deep insights into the ecosystem dynamics formed by the various social actors as they respond to external forces and trends  (b) Recognize the importance of cultural identity and branding in the design process (c) Use brainstorming and visualization as a means to frame and solve problems (d) Storyboarding role playing the user journey (e) Build and test out prototypes to expedite the learning process  3. Technology Platform and Business Model for Sustainable Innovation (a) The cloud and big data environment (b) Platforms and frameworks for industry disruption and transformation (c) Using technology (including crowd sourcing and open-innovation resources) to gain competitive and process advantages (d) Business model mapping for product-market fit  (e) Validate user and customer adoption with Kickstarter, user testing, social media, and field observation

title: Social Service: Participation and Reflection
requirements:
For United College students to take in their second year and third year of study only.
Social Work major students cannot take the course to fulfill General Education requirements.
description: The objective of this course is to foster students to become positive and responsible citizens through participating in community social service. Based on the principles of service-learning and theories of experiential learning, the course assists students to consolidate their prior and on-going community service experiences. Through self reflection, small group discussion, community agency visits and project presentation, students will be able to understand the needs of vulnerable groups, aware of human issues related to social justice and develop positive attitude to community social service. The purpose of this course is to facilitate students’ self development and develop a long-term interest in serving the community and populations in need.
outcome: After completion of this course, students will be able to: Understand the theory and practice of service-learning and social enterprisingness; Integrate community service or social enterprise visit experiences with the related principles; Relate their experiential-learning experience with the concepts of civic responsibility and social justice; Critically appraise their personal development in relation to their experiential-learning experience; Develop an awareness towards populations in need and identify ways to serve them; and Initiate long-term interest to serve the community and society; and Practice constant self-reflection in order to achieve self-discovery and self-expression.Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme: understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values; recognize the common concerns of the contemporary world; demonstrate social enterprisingness in protecting the environment and serving the community; and develop life-long learning habits for expanding interest and improving life-style.

title: Public Affairs: Participation and Reflection
requirements:
For United College students to take in their second or third year of study.
Government and Public Administration major students cannot take this course to fulfill General Education requirements.
description: This course aims to foster students’ sense of citizenship and leadership by enhancing their ability to understand and analyse political and social problems. It is not confined to the technical training of political and policy analysts, but broadened to the liberal education of citizens who have the knowledge, attitudes and competence to participate in public affairs. The purpose of the course is to raise the awareness of students towards social issues, nurture their ability to identify and analyse the pivotal aspects of the issues, and most importantly, encourage the students to form their own opinions and to suggest solutions. In line with this purpose, the course is issue-oriented, with controversial issues cutting across the discussions and reflections. Apart from classroom teaching and discussion, there will also be field trips to government agencies as well as non-government organizations, in which students will have opportunities to directly exchange ideas and opinions with government officials, community leaders and ordinary people.

title: Social Innovation: Social Enterprises and Demand
requirements: For Year 2 or above United College students only.
description: This course is designed to equip students with a basic understanding of social enterpreneurship through whole experience learning, not just the actual academics. Social entrepreneurship education is about collaboration, multi-disciplinary learning, learning-by-doing, problem-solving, and tackling the “real” problems. Through self-reflection, small group discussion, experiential learning by participating in social enterprise workshops and project presentations, students will be able to understand more the needs of underprivileged groups and the challenges of social enterprises. The purpose of this course is to facilitate students to learn more about the societal needs of the community and develop an innovative mindset to solve social issues.

title: Social Service in action: Participation and Reflection
requirements: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
description: The objective of this course is to foster students to become positive and responsible citizens through participating in service learning activity to community. Based on the principles of service-learning, social enterprisingness, and theories of experiential learning, the students are required to plan and implement a series of direct services, or other modes of service-learning for selected socially disadvantaged groups. Through self-reflection, small group discussion, and project presentation, students will be able to understand the needs of vulnerable groups, develop positive attitude to service learning and community social services. The purpose of this course is to facilitate students’ self-development and long-term interest in caring of the community for sustainable development.SDG#11: Sustainable Cities and CommunitiesSocial service addresses the needs of vulnerable or disadvantaged groups within our community. By providing support and resources, our service learning activities help to develop sustainable supporting networks and ensure all members of the community have access to it.
outcome: After completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Understand the theory and practice of service-learning and social enterprise 2. Integrate community service or other service-learning modes with the related principles 3. Relate their service-learning experience with the concepts of civic responsibility and sustainable development (SDG#11) 4. Critically appraise their personal development in relation to their service-learning experience 5. Develop an awareness towards populations in need and identify ways to serve them 6. Initiate long-term interest to serve the community and society 7. Practice constant self-reflection in order to achieve self-discovery and self-expression   Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme: 1. Understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values 2. Recognise the common concerns of the contemporary world 3. Demonstrate social enterprise in protecting the environment and serving the community 4. Develop life-long learning habits for expanding interest and improving life-style   SDG#11: Sustainable Cities and Communities: 1. Engage with local communities and contribute to initiatives that promote sustainable community development

title: Public Affairs in action: Participation and Reflection
requirements: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
description: The course aims to cultivate students' sense of citizenship and leadership. In addition to covering fundamental concepts and methods related to social issues and policy analysis, the primary goal of the course is to develop students' knowledge, attitudes, and abilities to participate in public affairs. Therefore, the course will focus on social issues, using controversial topics throughout the curriculum to stimulate students' interest and discussion regarding public affairs. Besides classroom learning, the course will arrange for students to participate in service activities with government agencies, public institutions, and non-governmental organisations, allowing them to experience the operations of government and non-profit organisations and have opportunities to learn and grow from these experiences. These experience will also help students to understand the SDG #11 to make the cities and human settlement inclusive, safe , resilient and sustainable.
outcome: This course will furnish students with the following capacities and skills:   1.Throughout the course, students are expected to master the basic concepts in policy analysis and be able to apply them to analyse real-world problems. More specifically, the students are expected to develop some basic knowledge of different features of civil society, social movement and governance.   2. By taking this course, the students are expected to be familiar with a wide range of practical problems besting the ordinary citizens in Hong Kong and the Mainland China. The students are encouraged to consider and observe the ways in which civil society can help to tackle and resolve these problems, and whether too much hope is placed on civil society.   3.This course is intended to develop the students into active and considerate citizens. In order to become good citizens, they must master generic skills in terms of articulating and communicating complicated ideas and analytical results effectively in both verbal and written formats. These skills are unlikely to emerge automatically. They have to be deliberately nurtured. In this course, through face-to-face interaction with social participants, and presentations and discussion exercises, the students are offered a well-organised setting where their analytical and communicating skills can burgeon.    Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:  1. Describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields  2. Understand the meaning of service-learning and reflect on the experience learnt through different types of community service  3. Foster comprehensive awareness in the sustainable development goals  4. Develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork  5. Identify and apply sustainable development tools and strategies to address social problems to achieve SGD #11
syllabus: Lecture Plan   Week One: Civil Society and the State   Theme: This lecture introduces the concepts of the state and civil society. It studies the challenges that the contemporary governments encounter in doing public governance from a state-society interaction perspective.   Week Two: Social Movement   Theme: This topic aims at providing a general picture of the development, processes and characteristics of traditional and new social movements, particularly in relation to the theoretical framework of state-civil society relations discussed in previous topic.   Week Three/Four: Service-learning activities   Week Five/Six/Seven: Group presentation and discussion

title: Social Innovation: Social Entrepreneurship and Service
requirements: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
description: This course is designed to equip students with a basic understanding of social entrepreneurship through experiential learning, not just the actual academics. Social entrepreneurship education is about collaboration, multi-disciplinary learning, learning-by-doing, problem-solving, and tackling the “real” problems. Through self-reflection, small group discussion, experiential learning by participating in social enterprise workshops and project presentations, students will be able to understand more the needs of underprivileged groups and the challenges of social enterprises. The purpose of this course is to facilitate students to learn more about the societal needs of the community and develop an innovative mindset to solve social issues. Service-learning activities are added to strengthen students' first-hand experience in real social enterprise situations.SDG#8: Decent Work and Economic GrowthSDG#10: Reduced InequalitiesSDG#11: Sustainable Cities and CommunitiesSocial enterprises serve various beneficiaries/disadvantaged groups. They solve different social issues through sustainable social innovation projects, reduce inequalities in our community and promote inclusive and sustainable economic growth by business operations.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, student should be able to: 1. Get a basic understanding about the nature and types of social enterprises 2. Identify the societal needs of underprivileged groups in Hong Kong 3. Understand the strategic positions of social enterprises in social betterment 4. Understand the advantages of social enterprises in response to social needs 5. Plan to solve a real challenge that social enterprise is facing   Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme: 1. Understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values 2. Recognize the common concerns of contemporary world 3. Understand the meaning of service-learning and reflect on the experience learnt through different types of community service 4. Develop life-long learning habits for expanding interest and improving life-style   SDG#8: Decent Work and Economic Growth: 1. Understand how social enterprises maintain sustainable economic growth by business operations 2. Recognize social enterprises’ practices to provide decent work SDG#10: Reduced Inequalities: 1. Recognize social enterprises or other business practices to embrace social inclusion and reduce inequalities SDG#11: Sustainable Cities and Communities: 1. Engage with local communities and contribute to initiatives that promote sustainable community development
syllabus: Lecture themes   1. What is Social Innovation / Social Enterprise? Social Enterprises in Hong Kong 2. Real cases sharing by Social Enterprises in understanding their Missions and Challenges 3. Social Enterprise Workshops - social enterprise human libraries 4. Resourcefulness - Through circle of influence and multi-disciplinary collaborations (e.g. social capital, CSR,CSV) 5. Innovation mindset - Turning problems into innovative ideas and practice the ideas via service learning activities 6. Final Presentation and Evaluation - present an idea how to support a designed social enterprise from a youth perspective *These topics aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of social enterprises, learn from real-world practices, and encourage innovative thinking and collaboration to fulfill social needs.

title: Leadership in Practice: Service
requirements: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
description: This course will explore and examine leadership theory and practice through experiential learning in outdoor settings, rather than being limited to classroom learning. Students will apply theoretical concepts to real-world situations through practice, enhancing their understanding of leadership principles. The course also includes elements of service learning, such as activities related to environmental protection like trail restoration, providing students with practical team leadership and hands-on experience that positively impacts the community and the environment (SDG #15 Life on Land).Participating in trail restoration not only fosters teamwork and communication but also cultivates a sense of responsibility toward environmental protection. Students will learn how to navigate challenges, communicate effectively, and motivate their peers as they work toward a common goal. Additionally, this experience will enable students to reflect on their own leadership styles and adapt them to different contexts, further strengthening their ability to lead diverse teams.Moreover, by sharing this knowledge and experience to the public, students will help cultivate a broader culture of environmental awareness and community involvement. They will prepare workshops to share insights gained from service-learning activities, such as trail restoration. These workshops may include hands-on demonstrations, discussions on sustainable practices, and the importance of environmental protection. By collaborating NGOs, students will also host clean-up trail workshops, tree-planting activities, or exhibitions, which not only educate the public but also actively involve them in environmental action. These service learning activities will inspire a collective commitment to sustainability and social responsibility , creating lasting environmental awareness within the community.
outcome: Upon successfully completing this course, students will be able to: 1. Execute the five main leadership functions which required by Action-centered Leadership 2. Coordinate members to work together as an effective team 3. Apply problem solving strategies in tackling the assigned leadership task 4. Exhibit skills in communication in maintaining the morale of the team 5. Construct their own conception of leadership.    Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:  1. Describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields  2. Understand the meaning of service-learning and reflect on the experience learnt through different types of community service  3. Foster comprehensive awareness in the sustainable development goals  4. Develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork  5. Identify and apply sustainable development tools and strategies to address social problems to achieve SDG#15
syllabus: This subject aims to bring out students’ firm understanding of the vital attributes of leadership skills for meeting the training needs of today’s young people. It places students in a simulated situation and coaches them to be responsible for dealing with problems, challenges and routine skills when training students to be practical, sensible and helpful in our society. The theory of outdoor experiential training for leadership and team building is that leadership skills can be honed and team spirit developed by taking students into the great outdoors. This concept features both physical and mental exercises. Key theories about leadership will be introduced with their practical applications for leadership including the follows: 1. Defining leadership 2. Leadership and management 3. Nature of leadership and leadership styles 4. Action-centred leadership 5. Leadership checklist 6. Time management for leaders 7. title: Design Thinking: Action for Service
requirements: For Year 2-3 United College students only.
description: This course aims to cultivate students' "T-shaped" learning qualities, enabling them to expand their skills within their major while also communicating and collaborating with individuals from different disciplines.Integrating design thinking into a service learning course enhances students' ability to develop creative and effective solutions to community challenges. The process begins with empathy, where students understand community needs through interviews and observations. They then define the problem based on their findings. Implementation involves putting the viable solution into action, requiring collaboration and project management. Throughout the process, reflection is encouraged to help students understand the impact of their work and foster personal growth. This course not only enhances problem-solving skills but also ensures that solutions are tailored to meet real community needs, promoting meaningful and sustainable impact. Students will be linked with various NGOs and social enterprises to design solutions that assist beneficiaries. For example, students will participate in Elderly-oriented Home Transformation Service and apply design thinking knowledge to assist the elderly in redesigning their homes and enhancing the living quality of the elderly. Various project groups within the course focuses on different sustainable development goals, such as no poverty (SDG#1), elderly needs, healthy lives and well-being (SDG#3). Through service-learning activities, students and community members are expected to enhance their cohesiveness and deepen their concerns for the local community (SDG＃11).

title: Senior Seminar
description: This is a compulsory three-unit and small-group student-orientated teaching (STOT) course for final year students, with teaching staff serving as supervisors, the emphasis will be on students’ participation and discussion. Student groups will choose a topic of their own interests, conduct research studies, present their findings and submit a report.The course objectives include:1. Arousing students’ interest in exploring contemporary local or global issues; 2. Sharpening research, problem-solving and thesis-writing skills; and3. Enhancing ability in conducting group research projects and seminars which require a collective effort.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes: recognize the common concerns of the contemporary world; describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields; demonstrate the ability to think independently and innovatively; cultivate comprehensive views to appreciate different cultures; and develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork.
syllabus: As it is a STOT course, no specific subject contents will be taught in the class. Student groups will pick their own research topics and conduct formal research, present findings and prepare written report.    The course arrangements are as follows:    1. Pre-course registration and topic selection  2. Meetings and communication with respective class supervisors 3. Work out research plans  4. Literature review or background research  5. Setup milestones or schedule for the research processes  6. Conduct research via appropriate means (questionnaire, survey, interview, focus group, etc)  7. Confirm research findings, explore implications and limitations  8. Prepare oral presentations  9. Prepare written reports

requirements:
1. For students of United College.
2. Pre-requisite: GEUC2103 or GEUC2213
description: This is an advanced experiential-learning course that will give students an opportunity to work directly for social enterprises under the guidance of their supervisors and professional mentors. Students would have opportunities to experience how the social enterprises help the underprivileged groups and gain hands-on business experience, which will strengthen their soft skills, help them implement the innovative business and promotional ideas in a practical way, and will greatly improve their understanding on the societal needs of the community, and the sustainable development directions and modes.This course is designed to immerse students in the world of social enterprise. This course enables students to further develop career and apply leadership-ready skills in the operation of a social enterprise or social business. Students are encouraged to provide ideas to promote the designated social enterprise among the youth community, and they will also have an opportunity to undertake an internship in a real social enterprise setting.
outcome: After completion of this course, students will be able to:  Integrate and apply theoretical knowledge in service leadership or the concepts of sustainable development;  Demonstrate an understanding of the ways in which social enterprise initiatives and the humanities and social sciences research skills, methods, knowledge and information are relevant to post-university working life and advance career prospects and applications;  Demonstrate a degree of professional expertise commensurate with an intensive period of practical hands-on experience through providing ideas to promote the social enterprise among youth community;  Adjust to a real-life work setting and understand the organizational culture of a social business;  Exchange ideas and experiences with partners, resolve differences, mutually enhance personal development and accomplish tasks through collaboration Students will achieve the following desirable learning outcomes of the College General Education Programme:  Understand the College motto and develop positive attitudes and values  Recognize the common concerns of contemporary world  Demonstrate social enterprisingness in protecting the environment and serving the community  Describe connections and integrate knowledge across fields  Develop leadership skills, and be able to collaborate and communicate effectively in teamwork
syllabus: Pre-Internship Preparation Activities  Pre-Internship orientation   Aim and objective of Internship  Nature, mission and business of the attached social enterprises   Roles and Responsibilities of students, supervisor and social enterprise supervisor  Concepts related to sustainable development goals  Workplace etiquette, work attitude and professional ethics at work  Practical arrangement    First meeting with the designated social enterprise   Meeting the social enterprise supervisor and self-introduction  Social enterprise and work place orientation  Working hours and practices arrangement    Creation of action plan   Preparing workplan to social enterprise supervisor  Workplan progress update process and timeline  Agreeing on measurement  Mutually agree on internship expectation and outcomes      During-Internship Learning Activities  Internship work, including action plan   Keeping work journal  Updating action plan periodically  Obtaining periodic feedback from social enterprise supervisor    Mid-term and final reports   Mid-term progress report to supervisor  Final report (draft version) to supervisor       Post-Internship Consolidation Activities  Final debriefing with the supervisor   Obtaining social enterprise evaluation report  Completing self-evaluation report  Meeting supervisor for debriefing    Final presentation   Presentation to supervisor and social enterprise supervisor  Final report submission with revision after final presentation
